Award.AwardTitle: Broadband Nonlinear Absorbing Iridium(III) Complexes: Optimizing the Linear and Nonlinear Absorption via Rational Design
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is jointly funded by the Electronic and Photonic Materials Program (EPM) in the Division of Materials Research and by the Chemical Structure, Dynamics and Mechanisms B Program (CSDM B) in the Division of Chemistry (CHE).

Non-technical Description: Nonlinear optical materials with strong and broadband nonlinear absorption (the absorptivity of the materials changes with the incident light intensity) are needed for numerous applications in information and image processing technology, such as optical switching, optical rectification, up-conversion lasing, three-dimensional optical data storage, and photodynamic therapy. This project focuses on studying the structure-property correlations in heavy transition-metal complexes with the aim to better understand how the chemical structural modifications influence their linear and nonlinear optical properties. With this understanding, synthesis of transition-metal complexes with broadband spectral (400-900 nm) and temporal (from picoseconds to continuous-wave) coverage can be a reality. The success of this project could provide a comprehensive picture of the relationship between nonlinear absorption and molecular structure, which enables a systematic design procedure for nonlinear absorbing materials. The structure-property correlations explored in this project could also be readily applied to other transition-metal complexes. This research is highly interdisciplinary. It provides students and postdoctoral researchers opportunities to gain knowledge and skills in organic synthesis, coordination chemistry, spectroscopic characterization, nonlinear optical measurements, and theoretical simulations. The interdisciplinary training motivates students' interest in research, and strengthens the workforce for the 21st Century. In addition, as part of the project effort, educational outreach activities involve the Native American students and high school students and inspire them to pursue future careers in materials research.

Technical Description: Mononuclear and dinuclear heteroleptic cationic iridium(III) complexes with substituted 2-(2-quinolinyl)quinoxaline (quqo) ligand and various cyclometalating ligands are selected with the aim of understanding the structure-property correlations and achieving broadband nonlinear absorption in the Ir(III) complexes. These complexes are chosen because the strong spin-orbit coupling induced by the Ir(III) ion could lead to high triplet excited-state quantum yield, not only through rapid intersystem crossing but also through direct transition from the singlet ground state (S0) to the lowest triplet excited state (T1). The spin-forbidden S0-to-T1 absorption gives rise to broad and weak ground-state absorption in the 500-800 nm regime when appropriate diimine ligands are used, which is desirable for broadband reverse saturable absorbers. In addition, many of the Ir(III) complexes possess broadband excited-state absorption in the visible to the near-IR regions; and the structures of the Ir(III) complexes could be readily modified. In this project, mononuclear and dinuclear Ir(III) complexes with different pi-conjugations, substituents, and varied substitution positions on the quqo and/or cyclometalating ligands are synthesized. Their ground-state and excited-state properties, and nonlinear absorption, as well as the effect of inter- and intramolecular interactions on the photophysics and nonlinear absorption of these complexes in high concentration solutions and solid state are investigated systematically via a combination of spectroscopic characterizations and density functional theory (DFT) calculations. The combined experimental-theoretical approach allows the team to establish the correlations between nonlinear absorption and molecular structure of Ir(III) complexes and enables a rational design of materials with well-controlled broadband nonlinear absorption.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major goal of this project was to understand the structure-property correlations in Ir(III) complexes in order to obtain materials with optimal broadband nonlinear absorption.

 

Through the four-year efforts, we synthesized 114 mono- or multi-nuclear Ir(III) complexes and 10 Ru(II) complexes, systematically investigated their photophysical properties, especially their ground-state and excited-state absorption (ESA), via spectroscopic techniques and computational simulations.  We have thoroughly investigated the effects of extended p-conjugation of the diimine ligands and/or cyclometalating ligands on the photophysics and reverse saturable absorption (RSA) of monocationic biscyclometalating Ir(III) complexes.  We discovered that extending the p-conjugation of the diimine ligands via attaching p-conjugated substituents by a single or a triple bond switched the lowest triplet excited state (T1) to the substituted-diimine ligand localized 3p,p*/3ILCT (intraligand charge transfer) state, which prolonged the triplet lifetime to tens of ms and broadened the ESA from the visible to the near-IR region.  On the other hand, the similar substitution at the cyclometalating ligand mixed more charge transfer character into the T1 state, which shortened the triplet lifetimes of the complexes and weakened the excited-state absorption.  However, these approaches did not impact the lowest-energy charge-transfer absorption band pronouncedly.  In contrast, expanding the p-conjugation of the diimine and/or cyclometalating ligands via benzannulation could cause a significant red-shift of the lowest-energy absorption band.  Appropriately adjusting the p-conjugation of the diimine and/or cyclometalating ligands could red-shift the lowest-energy absorption band to ca. 850 nm.  Meanwhile, the much red-shift ground-state absorption lowered the T1 energies and shortened the triplet lifetimes and weakened the ESA.  However, by incorporation of p-conjugated substituents to the appropriate core diimine ligands, we obtained Ir(III) complexes with broad and weak ground-state absorption extending to the near-IR region and long-lived T1 states and broad and strong ESA for optical limiting applications.  We also revealed that the benzannulation site at the diimine or the cyclometalating ligands drastically impacted the energies of the lowest singlet and triplet excited states, the T1 lifetimes, and the ESA.  By analyzing the frontier molecular orbital symmetry via density functional theory calculations, we better understood such a site-dependent benzannulation effect and successfully predicted the benzannulation sites that gave rise to the desired photophysical properties for reverse saturable absorbers.  Additionally, we investigated the effects of electron-donating or withdrawing substituents on the diimine ligand, the effects of multinuclear complexes vs. mononuclear complexes, the effects of tris-bidentate vs. bis-terdentate ligand coordination, and the number of charges on the photophysics and RSA.  Via better understanding of the structure-property correlations, we successfully obtained multiple Ir(III) complexes with broadband RSA in the visible to the near-IR region and reasonably long-lived T1 states for broadband optical limiting applications.

We also discovered that some of the Ir(III) complexes exhibited aggregation induced emission, and drastic mechanochromic, vapochromic, or thermal chromic effects, which have potential applications in bioimaging, vapor/temperature/pressure sensing, or security printing.  Some of the complexes and a large number of diimine ligands have the potential to be used as acid/base, cation (such as Zn2+ ion), or anion sensors.

In addition, we found that many of the Ir(III) complexes exhibited strong photodynamic therapeutic effect toward cancer cells and microbial upon broadband visible light activation.  We developed Ir/Ru complex – BODIPY dyads that absorbed strongly in the green to far-red spectral region, possessed long-lived T1 states and good singlet oxygen generation efficiency.  Some dyads can efficiently generate other reactive oxygen species in vitro.  The dyad absorbs strongly at 660 nm can generate hyperthermia upon red light activation.  These dyads have the potential for phototherapy toward cancers.

Based on some discoveries through this project, two provisional patent applications were filed in 2018.

This project provides ample training opportunities to 3 postdoctoral fellows (one female), 7 graduate students, and 4 visiting researchers (one female) on organic synthesis, coordination chemistry, materials characterization, spectroscopic and nonlinear optical characterization techniques, and theoretical simulations.  We also trained the involved personnel on data analysis, scientific writings and presentations.  All these opportunities would prepare future working forces for photonic materials research and development.  Two graduate students who had been actively involved in the theoretic simulations in this project successfully defended their Ph.D. dissertations in 2016 and 2017, and obtained postdoctoral positions in other research universities.  Another graduate student who played the major role in materials synthesis, characterization, and photophysical studies will defend his Ph.D. dissertation in Feb. 2019.

Both PIs actively participated in outreach activities organized for high school and undergraduate students interested in STEM disciplines, such as the North Dakota State Science Olympiad, the North Dakota NATURE program for Native American college students, and the NDSU welcome events.  These events aimed to attract talented students to STEM field; and popularize scientific thinking to a broader audience of high school students and their parents.  Both the PI and co-PI are female faculty, the support from this grant promoted their career development.


Last Modified: 11/28/2018
Modified by: Wenfang Sun
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: The major goal of this project was to understand the structure-property correlations in Ir(III) complexes in order to obtain materials with optimal broadband nonlinear absorption. Through the four-year efforts, we synthesized 114 mono- or multi-nuclear Ir(III) complexes and 10 Ru(II) complexes, systematically investigated their photophysical properties, especially their ground-state and excited-state absorption (ESA), via spectroscopic techniques and computational simulations. We have thoroughly investigated the effects of extended p-conjugation of the diimine ligands and/or cyclometalating ligands on the photophysics and reverse saturable absorption (RSA) of monocationic biscyclometalating Ir(III) complexes. We discovered that extending the p-conjugation of the diimine ligands via attaching p-conjugated substituents by a single or a triple bond switched the lowest triplet excited state (T1) to the substituted-diimine ligand localized 3p,p*/3ILCT (intraligand charge transfer) state, which prolonged the triplet lifetime to tens of ms and broadened the ESA from the visible to the near-IR region. On the other hand, the similar substitution at the cyclometalating ligand mixed more charge transfer character into the T1 state, which shortened the triplet lifetimes of the complexes and weakened the excited-state absorption. However, these approaches did not impact the lowest-energy charge-transfer absorption band pronouncedly. In contrast, expanding the p-conjugation of the diimine and/or cyclometalating ligands via benzannulation could cause a significant red-shift of the lowest-energy absorption band. Appropriately adjusting the p-conjugation of the diimine and/or cyclometalating ligands could red-shift the lowest-energy absorption band to ca. 850 nm. Meanwhile, the much red-shift ground-state absorption lowered the T1 energies and shortened the triplet lifetimes and weakened the ESA. However, by incorporation of p-conjugated substituents to the appropriate core diimine ligands, we obtained Ir(III) complexes with broad and weak ground-state absorption extending to the near-IR region and long-lived T1 states and broad and strong ESA for optical limiting applications. We also revealed that the benzannulation site at the diimine or the cyclometalating ligands drastically impacted the energies of the lowest singlet and triplet excited states, the T1 lifetimes, and the ESA. By analyzing the frontier molecular orbital symmetry via density functional theory calculations, we better understood such a site-dependent benzannulation effect and successfully predicted the benzannulation sites that gave rise to the desired photophysical properties for reverse saturable absorbers. Additionally, we investigated the effects of electron-donating or withdrawing substituents on the diimine ligand, the effects of multinuclear complexes vs. mononuclear complexes, the effects of tris-bidentate vs. bis-terdentate ligand coordination, and the number of charges on the photophysics and RSA. Via better understanding of the structure-property correlations, we successfully obtained multiple Ir(III) complexes with broadband RSA in the visible to the near-IR region and reasonably long-lived T1 states for broadband optical limiting applications. We also discovered that some of the Ir(III) complexes exhibited aggregation induced emission, and drastic mechanochromic, vapochromic, or thermal chromic effects, which have potential applications in bioimaging, vapor/temperature/pressure sensing, or security printing. Some of the complexes and a large number of diimine ligands have the potential to be used as acid/base, cation (such as Zn2+ ion), or anion sensors. In addition, we found that many of the Ir(III) complexes exhibited strong photodynamic therapeutic effect toward cancer cells and microbial upon broadband visible light activation. We developed Ir/Ru complex – BODIPY dyads that absorbed strongly in the green to far-red spectral region, possessed long-lived T1 states and good singlet oxygen generation efficiency. Some dyads can efficiently generate other reactive oxygen species in vitro. The dyad absorbs strongly at 660 nm can generate hyperthermia upon red light activation. These dyads have the potential for phototherapy toward cancers. Based on some discoveries through this project, two provisional patent applications were filed in 2018. This project provides ample training opportunities to 3 postdoctoral fellows (one female), 7 graduate students, and 4 visiting researchers (one female) on organic synthesis, coordination chemistry, materials characterization, spectroscopic and nonlinear optical characterization techniques, and theoretical simulations. We also trained the involved personnel on data analysis, scientific writings and presentations. All these opportunities would prepare future working forces for photonic materials research and development. Two graduate students who had been actively involved in the theoretic simulations in this project successfully defended their Ph.D. dissertations in 2016 and 2017, and obtained postdoctoral positions in other research universities. Another graduate student who played the major role in materials synthesis, characterization, and photophysical studies will defend his Ph.D. dissertation in Feb. 2019. Both PIs actively participated in outreach activities organized for high school and undergraduate students interested in STEM disciplines, such as the North Dakota State Science Olympiad, the North Dakota NATURE program for Native American college students, and the NDSU welcome events. These events aimed to attract talented students to STEM field; and popularize scientific thinking to a broader audience of high school students and their parents. Both the PI and co-PI are female faculty, the support from this grant promoted their career development. Last Modified: 11/28/2018 Submitted by: Wenfang Sun
